section.condition: TITLE=Trade Finance: Import Letter Of Credit
section.para: A Letter of Credit (LC) or Documentary Credit is a banking mechanism that enables importers to offer secure terms to exporters. It is an undertaking given by a bank (the Issuing Bank) on behalf of the buyer (applicant) to pay a seller (beneficiary) a given amount of money on presentation of specified documents guaranteeing the supply of goods within specific time limits. These documents, conforming to terms and conditions set out in the letter of credit, are to be presented at a specified place.

The module enables you, on behalf of your company (which is the importer and applicant), to initiate Letter of Credit requests, submit them to your chosen Issuing Bank, and subsequently amend, follow up and maintain them and exchange messages about them with this bank.
The basic functions found in all or most modules are described in chapter Functions. The chapter for each individual module gives details and differences specific to the module.

section.title: Import Letter of Credit Terminology
section.para: Within this section of the help guide, the terms "LC", "Letter Of Credit", "Import LC", and "Import Letter of Credit" are used interchangeably.
The terms "record" and "transaction" both refer to entries in the system relating to the function being discussed.

Enter the desired terms of a new Letter of Credit and submit them to the Issuing Bank of your choice.
From Template
Most of the information for the transaction is defaulted except key data such as the expiry date, currency and amount of the new LC.
Copy From LC
Requests that have been rejected by the bank have - -Not Processed- - in the Bank Reference column.
Upload LC
Create a Letter of Credit initiation by uploading a file.
Copy From LC
Create a Import Letter of Credit initiation from an existing Import Letter of Credit.
Back To Back LC

Retrieve Draft

Retrieve Unsigned

section.title: LC Initiation - Back to back LC
section.para: A Back-to-Back Credit is also known as a Counter Credit. It is often used as a method of finance to enable an export agent to buy goods from a supplier or manufacturer and sell them to a final buyer with a settlement effected by documentary credits.

In practice, the Back-to-Back LC can be described as an Import Letter of Credit initiated by the applicant from the details of an Export Letter of Credit for which the applicant is designated as the beneficiary.
When you select this option, you are presented with a list of your existing (non-purged) Export Commercial and Received Standby LCs.
You can then create an Import LC in a similar way to when you create one from an existing Import LC.
Note that the system does not prevent you from opening several LCs from the same Export LC record.
Complete or change the required fields in the rest of the form and click the Submit button at the top (or bottom) of the screen when ready.

section.title: LC Initiation - Retrieve Draft
section.para: This option allows an Import LC that you or another user have already started and saved, to be completed.

When selected, this option will present a list of FD Withdrawals that have been prepared and saved by users in your bank, but not yet submitted to the clients because the input user either did not try to submit or had insufficient privileges.
Click in the System Id column to open a message for further editing.

section.title: LC Initiation - Retrieve Unsigned
section.para: This option allows an Import LC that you or another user have already started but been unable to submit, to be submitted by an authorised user.

When selected, this option will present a list of FD Withdrawals that have been prepared and saved by users in your bank, but have not been successfully submitted to the clients because the user had insufficient privileges. Records that were simply saved with no attempt to submit them are not included.
Click in the System Id column to open the message in a non-editable mode, in order to review the data and perform the submission.

If you have sufficient authorisation in your profile, you can submit multiple records in a single operation directly from the list. Each record in the list has a check box which you tick to select it. A button at the end of the page submits all the selected records.

The result of the action is then returned, with a list of records that have now been successfully sent to the clients, together with a list of records that have again failed validation. The updated list of unsigned records is then also displayed.

section.para: As was explained in the Import Letter of Credit chapter, a Letter of Credit (LC) or Documentary Credit is a banking mechanism that enables importers to offer secure terms to exporters. See that chapter for further explanation.

Whereas the Import Letter of Credit module provides an interface for the applicant to request a Letter of Credit, this module (EL) provides an interface for the beneficiary to receive and follow up a Letter of Credit.

This module enables you, on behalf of your company (which is the exporter and beneficiary), to receive notification of Letters of Credit, and subsequent amendments or updates, from the Advising Bank. You can also send messages back to the bank for events that require your approval in the ongoing transaction flow, or to initiate a transfer.

section.title: Export Letter of Credit Terminology

Documentary Collection is a method of payment used in international trade, whereby the exporter entrusts the handling of trade documents to banks and gives the banks instructions concerning the release of these documents to the importer. The two most common conditions for release are:

listitem.para: Documents will be released only if the importer makes immediate payment according to the contracted agreement between the exporter and the importer. Also known as a sight Collection.
Documents will be released only if the importer accepts the accompanying draft, thereby incurring an obligation to pay at a specified future date. Also known as a term Collection.

section.para: The main advantages of Documentary Collection are that it is less complicated and less expensive than Letters of Credit - the documents are only released to the importer who needs them to fetch the goods when the payment or acceptance has been effected.
However, this method presents a greater risk to the exporter than do Letters of Credit, since no formal guarantee of payment is attached to its terms.
From its inception by the exporter to its ultimate recipient, the importer, the following parties are involved in a Documentary Collection:

listitem.para: The exporter (also known as the seller), who authorizes a bank (the Remitting Bank) to handle documents on its behalf.
The bank that the exporter authorizes to carry out the Collection on its behalf.
Any bank, other than the Remitting Bank, involved in obtaining payment or acceptance from the importer (drawee).
The Collecting Bank that presents the documents to the importer (drawee), usually the importer's bank.
The importer (also known as the buyer), who is presented with documents (financial and/or commercial) for the purpose of either payment or acceptance, in accordance with the Collection instructions.

section.title: Export Collection Terminology
section.para: Within this section of the help guide, the terms "EC", "Export Collection" and "Export Documentary Collection" are used interchangeably. The terms "record" and "transaction" both refer to entries in the system relating to the function being discussed.

section.title: Export Collection Step-by-Step Process
section.para: The classical flow of a transaction under a Documentary Collection is:

listitem.para: A sales contract is established with the buyer, whereby it is agreed that payment will be made by Documentary Collection.
The delivery of goods to the transport company (air/sea/land) is arranged by the exporter. He obtains transport documents from the carrier and prepares other documents as agreed with the importer.
The request to process the Collection is communicated to the Remitting Bank in one of two ways:

Regular Collection Instruction: the exporter gives a manually generated letter accompanied by the documents providing instructions on how to process the Collection to his Remitting Bank. This banks sends them on to the Presenting Bank.

Direct Collection Instruction: the exporter sends the documents directly to the Presenting Bank, often located in the country of the importer. He includes a cover letter bearing the Remitting Bank logo and indicating that they send the documents on its behalf. This method is usually used by exporters who settle large volumes of transactions through Collections.

The next step depends on the importer's response to the presentation of documents (payment, non-payment, acceptance of the bill of exchange, non-acceptance, protest, renegotiation, alternate buyer, etc.).

A Banker's Guarantee (BG) is a contract by which a third party (the guarantor, which here will be the bank) undertakes to be responsible for specific success and, in particular, to accept the damages which can result from a specific corporate transaction.
Based on this general definition, several specific types of guarantee can be handled. To name a few, the following ones are handled in as standard types of Banker's Guarantees:

listitem.para: a bid bond is given by a bidder for a construction contract to guarantee that the bidder, if awarded the contract within the time stipulated, will enter into the contract and furnish any performance and payment bonds that may be required.
a bond which guarantees performance of the terms of a written contract. Performance Bonds frequently, but not always, incorporate payment bond and maintenance bond liability.
a bond given by a contractor to guarantee payment to certain subcontractors, labourers and suppliers for the labour and material used in the work performed under the contract.

under the terms of a contract, a supplier may receive an advance of payment for the service provided. If he subsequently fails to deliver, this bond will ensure the reimbursement of that advanced amount to the buyer.
for each payment to be made by the Buyer, a certain portion is kept until the satisfying completion of the contracted work.

This document is the carnet referred to in the International Customs Convention on the A.T.A. Carnet for the Temporary Admission of Goods. It is an international document with which an importer posts security with the insurer of the carnet. The issuing body (often a national Chamber of Commerce) guarantees the payment of any duties and taxes if the condition of temporary importation is violated.

section.para: The life cycle of a guarantee generally starts with a request from the customer of the bank asking for issuance of a certain type of Guarantee. It may be followed by several forms of communication whose details vary from one type of guarantee to the other (including amendments of the guarantee's terms).

It generally ends with the submission to the bank of some details or documents implying the cancellation of the guarantee (e.g. The proof of completion of a contract under a Performance Bond), or the reach of its expiry date.

implements the applicant side of the customer-to-bank relationship. The bank involved is here considered as simply the recipient of the customer's request and potentially also the Issuing Bank of the guarantee.

This module enables you, on behalf of your company, to submit details of a new guarantee, request amendments to the terms of an existing guarantee, and engage in free format communications with the Recipient Bank and/or Issuing Bank concerning a guarantee.

A Financing Request or Trade Financing (TF) is a transaction issued in the by the client and sent to a designated bank (the lender, also called Issuing Bank of the loan in the rest of this document) whereby that import or export customer requests some form of financing for an International Trade transaction.

The use of the Financing Requests module is quite generic in the sense that it aims at providing transaction handling capabilities for various types of financing such as Import Loans, Export Discounts on a presentation of documents by an exporter, as well as Trust Receipts or for instance Export Pre-Financing.

To illustrate a possible use of this module, take the example of a Trust Receipt where the customer/importer is unable to pay for the cost of goods imported according to the terms of a Documentary Collection or even a Letter of Credit, and it is necessary for him to sell the goods first.

In such a case, the Financing Requests module would be used by the customer to submit his request by specifying the expected maturity date, the amount of the sale and the schedule of the goods whose possession is held by the bank under this Trust Receipt agreement.

For an Export Pre-Financing or a Packing Credit, an exporter could typically use the module to submit his request for financing and specify its maturity date, amount and typically the details of the invoices to finance.

This module enables you, on behalf of your company, to initiate new requests, send them to your chosen Issuing Bank, and subsequently follow up these transactions by sending and receiving updates on the records to and from the bank.

A Shipping Guarantee (SG) is an undertaking by a bank to the shipping owner or agent of a vessel, to release goods to the importer pending receipt of the original Bill of Lading. This helps the importer to clear the purchased goods under a Letter of Credit or a simple documentary collection while waiting for shipping documents to be presented. Hence it can for instance save the client from storage charges levied by the port authorities due to late arrival of the shipping documents or delays in clearance of the goods. Some Letters of Indemnity could also be handled through this module.

The module of enables you, on behalf of your company (which is the importer and applicant) to initiate new Shipping Guarantee requests, send them to your chosen Issuing Bank, and subsequently follow up these transactions by sending and receiving updates on the records to and from the bank.

The module enables you, on behalf of your company (the Importer), to Pay invoices for orders received from your seller (the Exporter).

This module also enables a user at the importer to enter invoices received from the exporter. This is called a lodge scenario, and is useful if the exporter does not have or does not have this module.
In this chapter we generally assume that your company is the Importer.
In this chapter, we use the terms importer and buyer interchangeably, and we use the terms exporter and seller interchangeably,

section.title: Invoice PayableTerminology
section.para: Within this section of the help guide, the terms "IP" and "Invoice Payable" are used interchangeably. The terms "record" and "transaction" both refer to entries in the system relating to the function being discussed.

section.title: Invoice Payable - Invoices and Open Accounts
section.para: An Open Account transaction is one where the goods are shipped and delivered before payment is due. Thus the seller is extending credit to the buyer. This is becoming increasingly common in international trade, compared to more traditional methods such as Letters of Credit.
In , an Open Account is a group of Invoices that have been stored together ready to be sent in a batch to an exporter.
A Seller can use to create Invoices and send them to the Buyer. The Buyer can then use this module to send the invoices to the bank.

section.title: Invoice Payable - Bank Involvement
section.para: The bank associated with these transactions is known as the Issuing Bank, just as in other modules, even though in this case it does not really issue anything. In this module the bank is more of an observer, since no bank approval is needed for Invoices and invoices to pass between buyer and seller.

If both the buyer and the seller are users of , the Invoices and invoices pass directly between them, and are sent to the Issuing Bank for information only, enabling the bank to offer services such as financing.

If only one of the companies is a user of , then communications between them are sent via the Issuing Bank. While one company uses to communicate with the bank, the other must use some other channel such as SWIFT TSU.

section.title: Invoice Payable - Counterparty Access
section.para: If your company (the Buyer) is not an existing user of , your Seller can arrange for you to have limited access to to use the modules.
When your Seller arranges for you to have access to , they should let you know the credentials (user ID, password, and abbreviated name for your company) you can use to log on.
Where a function may not be present if you have limited counterparty access, this chapter says so.

The module enables you, on behalf of your company (the exporter), to create invoices for orders received from your buyer (the importer).

This module also enables a user at the importer to enter invoices received from the exporter. This is called a lodge scenario, and is useful if the exporter does not have or does not have this module.
In this chapter we generally assume that your company is the exporter. Where a function is for use by the importer, this chapter says so.
In this chapter, we use the terms importer and buyer interchangeably, and we use the terms exporter and seller interchangeably,

section.title: Invoice Terminology
section.para: Within this chapter of the help guide, he terms importer and buyer interchangeably, the terms exporter and seller interchangeably and the terms "IN" and "Invoice" in reference to transactions, are used interchangeably . The terms "record" and "transaction" both refer to entries in the system relating to the function being discussed.

section.title: Invoice - Invoices and Open Accounts
section.para: An Open Account transaction is one where the goods are shipped and delivered before payment is due. Thus the seller is extending credit to the buyer. This is becoming increasingly common in international trade, compared to more traditional methods such as Letters of Credit.
In , an Open Account is a group of Invoices that have been stored together ready to be sent in a batch to an exporter.

Your buyer can use to create Invoices and send them to your company. You use this module to send the invoices. You use the module, described in chapter Purchase Order Advice Module, to receive and acknowledge the Invoices.

section.title: Invoice - Bank Involvement
section.para: The bank associated with these transactions is known as the Issuing Bank, just as in other modules, even though in this case it does not really issue anything. In this module the bank is more of an observer, since no bank approval is needed for invoices to pass between buyer and seller.
If both the buyer and the seller are users of , invoices pass directly between them, and are sent to the Issuing Bank for information only, enabling the bank to offer services such as financing.

If only one of the companies is a user of , then communications between them are sent via the Issuing Bank. While one company uses to communicate with the bank, the other must use some other channel such as SWIFT TSU.

section.title: Invoice - Counterparty Access
section.para: If your company (the seller) is not an existing user of , your buyer can arrange for you to have limited access to to use the and modules.
When your buyer arranges for you to have access to , they should let you know the credentials (user ID, password, and abbreviated name for your company) you can use to log on.

section.title: Invoice Maintenance
section.para: This function may not be present if you have limited counterparty access.

Perform maintenance tasks on invoice records handled by your company. You can assign an entity to a record, and you can delete from the system outdated transaction records or records whose status has been marked as Purged.

note.para: Deleted records are physically removed from the system. This task should therefore be conducted with great care!

section.title: Invoice Maintenance - Unsigned Invoices
section.para: List and optionally delete unsigned Invoice transactions.

When you select this option, you are presented with a list of Invoice records that are unsigned (unauthorised). Click in the System Id column to select the invoice for deletion, and click the "Delete selected transactions" button.
Note that this action is not validated against the Jurisdiction matrix.

section.title: Invoice Maintenance - Not Registered Invoices
section.para: List and optionally delete Not-registered Invoice transactions.

When you select this option, you are presented with a list of Invoice records that are Not-registered. Click in the System Id column to select the invoice for deletion, and click the "Delete selected transactions" button.
Note that this action is not validated against the Jurisdiction matrix.

section.title: Invoice Maintenance - Purged Orders
section.para: Display a list of invoices that have been marked as Purged by the Issuing Bank's Trade Services team (if your company does not have a direct connection to the bank's system, messages to purge invoices are sent by the bank to your system by other means such as SWIFT TSU). You cannot initiate further amendments or messages on such a transaction, and can only use its data for inquiry purposes.

You can delete multiple records in a single operation directly from the list. Each record in the list has a check box which you tick to select it. A button at the end of the page deletes all the selected records.
